Thus, A is the correct answer.

Question 22
When 18 is included in a list of natural numbers, the average of these numbers is increased by 2. When 8 is included in this new list of natural numbers, the average of these numbers in the new list remains the same. If there are N natural numbers in the original list of numbers and their average in X, find the value of N and X respectively.(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.5, 6
  • B.6, 8
  • C.8, 6
  • D.6, 5
Correct Answer: 5, 6

From 1st condition,

NX+18N+1 = X + 2 ------------(i)

From 2nd condition,

NX+18+8N+2 = X + 2 ------------(ii)

Solving both the equations, we get

N = 5 and X = 6

Question 23
A girl walks 12kmssouth from her house, turns left and walks 26kms, again turns left and walks 37kms. Again she turns right and walks 6kmsto reach her office. In which direction is the office of the girl from her house? (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.South-East
  • B.South
  • C.North-East
  • D.South-West
Correct Answer: North-East

Clearly, the office is in North-East direction.

Question 24
Fin the number that can replace question mark (?) in the series given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)20, 62, 189, 571, 1718, ?
  • A.5160
  • B.2160
  • C.3160
  • D.4660
Correct Answer: 5160

62 = 20 × 3 + 2

189 = 62 × 3 + 3

571 = 189 × 3 + 4

1718 = 571 × 3 + 5

Similarly,

1718 × 3 + 6 = 5160

Question 25
The selling price of 30 articles is equal to the purchase price of 25 articles. Find the percentage of profit or loss. (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.18% profit
  • B.1623% loss
  • C.18% loss
  • D.1623% profit
Correct Answer: 1623% loss

Let SP of 30 articles = x

SP of 25 particles = 2530 x = 56 x

CP of 25 particles = x

Loss = x - 56 x = 16 x

Loss % = 16 xx × 100 = 1623 %

Question 26
If the statement “All saints are materialists” is given as true, which of the following statements could be inferred to be true? (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.No saints are materialists
  • B.Some saints are materialists
  • C.Some saints are not materialists
  • D.Some materialists are not saints
Correct Answer: Some saints are materialists

Given statement is type ‘A’ and it is true. Therefore type ‘I’ will be true whic means option B is the correct answer.

Question 27
Which of the following statements are logically equivalent?A. All saints are materialistsB. No saints are non-materialistsC. All non-materialists are non-saintsD. No materialists are saintsChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.B, C & E only
  • B.A & C only
  • C.A & B only
  • D.A, B & C only
Correct Answer: A, B & C only

Option B is the obversion of option A which is type ‘A’.

Option C is the contraposition of option A which is type ‘A’.

Question 28
Which of the following statements are so related that they cannot both be false, though they can both be true?A. Some saints are materialistsB. All saints are materialistsC. No saints are not materialistsD. Some saints are not materialistsChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A & C only
  • B.A & D only
  • C.C & D only
  • D.B & D only
Correct Answer: A & D only

In case of subcontrary, statements are so related that they cannot both be false, though they can both be true. Therefore, correct answer is option B.

Question 29
“Of course XYZ political party is going to sweep the polls in the coming elections. Everybody is saying so”. Which informal fallacy is committed in the above statement?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Appeal to Emotion
  • B.Begging the question
  • C.slippery slope
  • D.Appeal to majority
Correct Answer: Appeal to majority

Appeal to majority fallacy assumes that something is true or correct simply because a majority of people believe it. The statement claims that XYZ political party will win the election because "everybody is saying so." This relies on the popularity of the opinion, not on any evidence of the party's potential success. Public opinion polls or widespread conversations might not always translate to actual voting outcomes.

Question 30
“All things are visible because they are knowable” which fallacy is committed in the above statement according to Classical Indian School of Logic (Nyaya)?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Sadharana
  • B.Anupasamhari
  • C.Asadharana
  • D.Virudhha
Correct Answer: Anupasamhari

Anupasamhari fallacy refers to the fallacy of the non-exclusive middle term. It occurs when the middle term (hetu) in a syllogism is used too broadly and encompasses situations where the major term (sadhya) might not be true. The statement assumes that "knowable" (hetu) is a characteristic that guarantees "visibility" (sadhya). However, the middle term is not exclusive to the major term. Not everything that is knowable is necessarily visible. We can know about things through touch, hearing, or even abstract concepts, which are not visible.

Question 31
Which of the following pair of acronym and its expansion is incorrectly matched?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.GPS – Global Positioning System
  • B.GSM -Global System for Management
  • C.SIM- Subscriber Identity Module
  • D.Wimax- WorldwideIntereoperabilityfor Microwave Access
Correct Answer: GSM -Global System for Management

Option B is correct.

GPS stands for Global Positioning System, which is a satellite-based navigation system that provides location and time information anywhere on Earth.

GSM stands for Global System for Mobile Communications, not "Global System for Management." It is a standard developed for mobile telecommunications that enables mobile devices to communicate with each other and with networks.

SIM stands for Subscriber Identity Module, which is a small card inserted into mobile phones to identify the user and authenticate their mobile network subscription.

WiMAX stands for Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access, which is a wireless communication standard that provides broadband wireless access over long distances.

Question 32
What does the following MS EXCEL formula do?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)SUM (Sheet1:Sheet4!D18)
  • A.It adds data from all D18 cells in sheet1, sheet2, sheet3, and sheet4
  • B.It adds data from cell D18 of sheet1 and cell D18 of sheet4
  • C.It adds all data in the range A1:D18 in sheet1, sheet2, sheet3, sheet4
  • D.It adds data from cell A1 of sheet1 and cell D18 of sheet4
Correct Answer: It adds data from all D18 cells in sheet1, sheet2, sheet3, and sheet4

Correct option is It adds data from all D18 cells in sheet1, sheet2, sheet3, and sheet4.

Question 33
Given below are two statements:Statement I:(11001000)2=(C8)16=(200)10Statement II:(123)10=(01111011)2=(7B)16In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are true

Both the statements are correct.

Question 34
Which of the following statements A-D apply to a laser printer?A. It uses a rotating drum to transfer the image of the paperB. It uses powdered tonerC. It uses nozzles to spray droplets on the paperD. It uses a print head mechanism that moves side to sideChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A & B only
  • B.C & D only
  • C.A & C only
  • D.B & D only
Correct Answer: A & B only

Option A is correct.

Laser printers use a rotating drum as part of the electrostatic printing process. The image of the document to be printed is formed on the drum through the application of laser light or other means. This image is then transferred onto the paper during the printing process.

Laser printers utilize powdered toner as the printing medium. Toner particles are attracted to the charged areas of the rotating drum, forming the desired image. The toner is then transferred onto the paper and fused into place using heat and pressure, resulting in the final printed output.

Inkjet printers, not laser printers, use nozzles to spray tiny droplets of ink onto the paper to create the printed image.

In inkjet printers, the print head moves side to side across the paper, depositing ink droplets to form the printed image. Laser printers, on the other hand, use a fixed print head and a rotating drum to transfer toner onto the paper.

Question 35
One component of the internal memory of a computer is Random Access Memory (RAM). Which of the following statements are correct about characteristics of RAM?A. RAM can be read from and written toB. RAM is volatile memoryC. RAM is temporary storageD. Modern PCs typically have from 2TBupto32TB of RAMChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.C & D only
  • B.A, B & C only
  • C.A & B only
  • D.A, B, C & D only
Correct Answer: A, B & C only

Option B is correct.

Characteristics of RAM are:

RAM (Random Access Memory) is a type of computer memory that allows data to be read from and written to. It serves as temporary storage for data and program instructions that are actively being used by the CPU.

Volatile memory is memory that loses its stored data when the power is turned off or lost. RAM is volatile memory, meaning that its contents are lost when the computer is powered off. This is in contrast to non-volatile memory, such as solid-state drives (SSDs) or hard disk drives (HDDs), which retain data even when the power is turned off.

RAM serves as temporary storage for data and program instructions that are actively being used by the computer. It allows the CPU to access and manipulate data quickly, but its contents are lost when the computer is powered off.

While modern PCs may have large amounts of RAM compared to earlier systems, they typically do not have 2TB to 32TB of RAM. Such amounts of RAM would be excessive for most consumer or even enterprise applications. Typically, modern PCs may have RAM capacities ranging from a few gigabytes (GB) to several tens of gigabytes, with high-end systems possibly reaching into the hundreds of gigabytes.

Question 36
Given below are two statements:Statement I: Chlorine is one of the most commonly used inexpensive chemical disinfectants for waterStatement II: Optimum Fluoride levels in drinking water help prevent cavities in childrenIn the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are true

Option A is correct.

Statement I is true. Chlorine is widely used as a chemical disinfectant to treat drinking water and swimming pool water. It effectively kills bacteria, viruses, and other microorganisms present in water, making it safe for human consumption or recreational use. Chlorination is a common and cost-effective method of water disinfection used worldwide.

Statement II is also true. Fluoride is known to prevent tooth decay and cavities, particularly in children. When consumed in appropriate amounts, fluoride strengthens tooth enamel, making teeth more resistant to decay caused by acids produced by bacteria in the mouth. Adding fluoride to drinking water at optimal levels has been recognized as a public health measure to improve dental health and reduce the prevalence of cavities.

Question 37
What is the full form of NBOD?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Neutral Biochemical Oxygen Demand
  • B.Natural Biochemical oxygen Demand
  • C.Normalized Biochemical Oxygen Demand
  • D.Nitrogenous Biochemical Oxygen Demand
Correct Answer: Nitrogenous Biochemical Oxygen Demand

Option D is correct.

NBOD stands for Nitrogenous Biochemical Oxygen Demand. It refers to the portion of the total biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) in water that is specifically attributed to the oxygen-consuming activities of nitrogenous organic compounds present in the water.

Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) is a measure of the amount of dissolved oxygen consumed by microorganisms while decomposing organic matter in water. NBOD specifically focuses on the contribution of nitrogenous organic compounds to this oxygen demand.

Question 38
Soot particles areA. are also called black carbonB. are mostly of coarse size rangeC. are toxicD. contribute in global warmingE. can penetrate in to deeper parts of lungsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A, B, C, D only
  • B.A, B, C E only
  • C.A, C, D, E only
  • D.B, C, D, E only
Correct Answer: A, C, D, E only

Option C is correct.

Soot particles, which are produced from incomplete combustion of organic matter such as fossil fuels, biomass, or wood, are often referred to as black carbon due to their dark color.

Soot particles can vary in size, including both fine and coarse particles. Fine soot particles, also known as particulate matter (PM2.5), are of particular concern due to their ability to penetrate deep into the lungs and cause health problems.

Soot particles contain a complex mixture of chemicals, including polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), which are known to be toxic and carcinogenic. Exposure to soot particles can lead to various adverse health effects, including respiratory issues, cardiovascular problems, and cancer.

Soot particles, especially black carbon, have a warming effect on the climate. When suspended in the atmosphere, they absorb sunlight and heat the surrounding air. Additionally, when deposited on snow and ice surfaces, they reduce their reflectivity (albedo), accelerating melting and contributing to climate change.

Fine soot particles, such as PM2.5, are small enough to bypass the body's natural defense mechanisms in the respiratory tract and penetrate deep into the lungs. Once inhaled, these particles can cause inflammation and damage to lung tissue and can even enter the bloodstream, posing systemic health risks.

Question 39
Ozone layer which protects us fromfromharmful ultraviolet radiations is situated in(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Troposphere
  • B.Stratosphere
  • C.Mesosphere
  • D.Ionosphere
Correct Answer: Stratosphere

Option B is correct.

The ozone layer, which protects us from harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun, is situated in the stratosphere.

The troposphere is the lowest layer of Earth's atmosphere, extending from the surface up to approximately 10 kilometers (6.2 miles) above sea level. The ozone concentration is relatively low in the troposphere compared to the stratosphere, and it is not primarily responsible for protecting against harmful UV radiation.

The ozone layer is located primarily in the stratosphere, which lies above the troposphere and extends from about 10 kilometers (6.2 miles) to 50 kilometers (31 miles) above the Earth's surface. The ozone layer absorbs the majority of the sun's harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation, preventing it from reaching the Earth's surface and protecting living organisms from its damaging effects.

The mesosphere is the layer of Earth's atmosphere above the stratosphere, extending from about 50 kilometers (31 miles) to 85 kilometers (53 miles) above the Earth's surface. While the mesosphere plays a role in filtering out some incoming radiation, it is not primarily responsible for protecting against UV radiation.

The ionosphere is a region of Earth's upper atmosphere, consisting of portions of the mesosphere, thermosphere, and exosphere, where atoms and molecules are ionized by solar and cosmic radiation. While the ionosphere plays a role in various atmospheric processes, it is not primarily associated with the protection against harmful UV radiation.

Question 40
The latest amendment to Montreal protocol is(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Kigali amendment
  • B.Nairobi amendment
  • C.Copenhagen amendment
  • D.Bangkok amendment
Correct Answer: Kigali amendment

Option A is correct.

The Kigali Amendment is the latest amendment to the Montreal Protocol. The Montreal Protocol is an international treaty designed to protect the ozone layer by phasing out the production and consumption of ozone-depleting substances (ODSs). The Kigali Amendment was adopted in October 2016 during a meeting held in Kigali, Rwanda.

The Kigali Amendment specifically addresses the phase-down of hydro fluorocarbons (HFCs), which are potent greenhouse gases with high global warming potential (GWP). While HFCs do not deplete the ozone layer like chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and other ODSs, they contribute significantly to climate change.

The Kigali Amendment aims to gradually reduce the production and consumption of HFCs, thereby helping to mitigate global warming and climate change while continuing to protect the ozone layer.

Question 41
Raja Ram Mohan Roy was responsible for the establishment of(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Agra college, Agra
  • B.Hindu college, Kolkata
  • C.Banaras Sanskrit college, Banaras
  • D.Seramporecollege,Serampore
Correct Answer: Hindu college, Kolkata

Option B is correct.

Raja Ram Mohan Roy, referred to as the "Father of the Indian Renaissance," played a significant role in various social, religious, and educational reforms in India during the 19th century.

One of his notable contributions was the establishment of the Hindu College in Kolkata (now known as Presidency University). The Hindu College was founded in 1817 with the aim of providing Western-style education to Indian students while also promoting Indian languages, literature, and culture.

The establishment of the Hindu College marked a significant development in the field of education in colonial India. It played a crucial role in spreading modern education and promoting critical thinking among Indian students, contributing to the emergence of a new intellectual class in the country.

Question 42
What were the important observation of Education Commission (Pre-Independence) 1882-83?A. There is a need to display the dispatch of 1854B. It is necessary to refashion the general working of Indian universitiesC. There is also a need for local governments to extend the facilities of general educationD. It is important to find each college depending upon staff strength, maintenance expenses and locality requirementsE. Special grants should be made available to improve the infrastructure of collegesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A, B, C only
  • B.B, C, D only
  • C.C, D, E only
  • D.A, D, E only
Correct Answer: C, D, E only

Option C is correct.

The important observation of Education Commission (Pre-Independence) 1882-83 were:

There is also a need for local governments to extend the facilities of general education. The commission highlighted the necessity for local governments to expand the facilities for general education, indicating a need for broader access to education across various regions.

It is important to find each college depending upon staff strength, maintenance expenses, and locality requirements. It corresponds with an important observation of the Education Commission. The commission emphasized the importance of assessing each college's needs based on factors such as staff strength, maintenance expenses, and locality requirements to ensure efficient management and resource allocation.

Special grants should be made available to improve the infrastructure of colleges also reflects a significant observation of the Education Commission. The commission recommended providing special grants to enhance the infrastructure of colleges, indicating a recognition of the importance of adequate facilities for promoting quality education.

Question 43
Match List I with the List IILIST I (Authority / Viceroy)(a) Lord Ripon(b) LordCuzron(c) William Bentinck(d) Government of IndiaLIST (Commission Chairman)(i)SarvapaliRadhakrishnan(ii) Thomas Babington Macaulay(iii) W.W Hunter(iv) T. RaleighChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(ii), (c)-(i), (d)-(iv)
  • B.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iv), (d)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
  • D.(a)-(iv), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii), (d)-(i)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)

Option C is correct.

Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan correctly matches with Government of India.

Thomas Babington Macaulay correctly matches with William Bentinck.

W.W. Hunter correctly matches with Lord Curzon.

T. Raleigh correctly matches with Lord Ripon.

Question 44
Given below are two statements:Statement I: Curriculum atTaxilawas varied and included technical issuesStatement II: Curriculum ofNalandaexcluded technical sciencesIn the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are true

Option A is correct.

Statement I is true. Taxila, one of the ancient centers of learning in the Indian subcontinent, had a diverse curriculum that encompassed various subjects, including technical and practical disciplines such as mathematics, astronomy, medicine, military science, and others. The curriculum at Taxila aimed to provide a comprehensive education covering a wide range of fields.

Statement II is also true. Nalanda, another renowned ancient center of learning in India, primarily focused on subjects related to philosophy, religion, literature, and the arts. While Nalanda offered an extensive curriculum covering a wide range of subjects such as Buddhist studies, logic, grammar, and metaphysics, it did not emphasize technical sciences or practical disciplines to the same extent as Taxila.

Question 45
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason RAssertion A: It is escaped that a meaningful partnership will be formed between the states and the union Government is managing EducationReason R: Education is concurrent subject as per the constitutional amendment of 1976In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is true but R is false
  • D.A is false but R is true
Correct Answer: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A

Option A is correct.

Assertion A is true. In India, education is a concurrent subject, which means that both the central (Union) government and the state governments have the authority to legislate and make policies regarding education. Therefore, a meaningful partnership between the states and the Union Government is essential for effective management of education.

Reason R is also true and it correctly explains assertion A. The 42nd Amendment Act of 1976 made significant changes to the Indian Constitution, including the addition of education to the Concurrent List (List III) of the Seventh Schedule. This means that both the central and state governments have the power to make laws on matters related to education. The concurrent status of education allows for collaboration and coordination between the central and state governments in managing the education system.

Question 46
Climate change will have broad impact on human society. Changes projected to occur in the coming century or two won’t have the apocalyptic, civilization-destroying character of, say an all-out nuclear war or a direct hit from a large asteroid. But climate change will be disruptive in many ways to a civilization whose planetary home is already under stress from the demands of billions of human beings.The physical impacts of climate change won’t be evenly distributed around the globe. Low-lying coastal regions, for example, will suffer more from sea-level rise, continental interiors will see more drought and high latitudes will warm disproportionately. For that reason alone, impacts will vary from country to country. But also alter the impact of changing climate, social, political and economic considerations. That’s because wealthier countries are better able to adapt to and counter deleterious effects. Wealthy countries can build protective seawalls to ward off the rising oceans; they can engineer massive water projects to ensure continuing supplies of freshwater; they can outbid poorer countries if declines in domestic agriculture require increased food imports their advanced health care systems can better cope with spreading tropical diseases; and their robust economies can speed recovery from extreme weather events. We’re forced to the unfortunate conclusion that climate change will exacerbate the gap between rich and poor nations, as those with the fewest resources will be most vulnerable. This conclusion should be especially troubling because anthropogenic climate change is almost ‘entirely the result of fossil fuel consumption, deforestation and other activities carried out by or for the benefit of the developed world.Impact of climate change on human society will be(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Inconsequential
  • B.As disastrous as the impact of a nuclear war
  • C.Disruptive
  • D.Mild
Correct Answer: Disruptive

The passage describes how climate change will have broad and disruptive impacts on human society, although it may not reach the apocalyptic level of a nuclear war or a direct hit from a large asteroid. It highlights how climate change will affect different regions differently, with low-lying coastal areas suffering from sea-level rise, continental interiors experiencing more drought, and high latitudes warming disproportionately. Additionally, the passage discusses how social, political, and economic factors will influence the impact of climate change, with wealthier countries being better able to adapt and counter its effects compared to poorer nations. Therefore, the most appropriate description of the impact of climate change on human society based on the passage is "disruptive" (option C).

Question 47
Climate change will have broad impact on human society. Changes projected to occur in the coming century or two won’t have the apocalyptic, civilization-destroying character of, say anall-out nuclear war or a direct hit from a large asteroid. But climate change will be disruptive in many ways to a civilization whose planetary home is already under stress from the demands of billions of human beings.The physical impacts of climate change won’t be evenly distributed around the globe. Low-lying coastal regions, for example, will suffer more from sea-level rise, continental interiors will see more drought and high latitudes will warm disproportionately. For that reason alone, impacts will vary from country to country. But also alter the impact of changing climate, social, political and economic considerations. That’s because wealthier countries are better able to adapt to and counter deleterious effects. Wealthy countries can build protective seawalls to ward off the rising oceans; they can engineer massive water projects to ensure continuing supplies of freshwater; they can outbid poorer countries if declines in domestic agriculture require increased food imports their advanced health care systems can better cope with spreading tropical diseases; and their robust economies can speed recovery from extreme weather events. We’re forced to the unfortunate conclusion that climate change will exacerbate the gap between rich and poor nations, as those with the fewest resources will be most vulnerable. This conclusion should be especially troubling because anthropogenic climate change is almost ‘entirely the result of fossil fuel consumption, deforestation and other activities carried out by or for the benefit of the developed world.In the context of climate change which among the following statements are not correct? (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)A. Low-lying areas will be threatenedB. Agricultural production will be affectedC. Developing countries will adapt better to itD. Health will be affectedE. Developed countries will suffer less
  • A.C & E only
  • B.A, B & C only
  • C.A, C & E only
  • D.A, D & E only
Correct Answer: C & E only

A. Low-lying areas will be threatened: This statement is supported by the passage, which mentions that low-lying coastal regions will suffer more from sea-level rise due to climate change.

 

B. Agricultural production will be affected: This statement is supported by the passage, which discusses how declines in domestic agriculture may require increased food imports, impacting agricultural production.

 

C. Developing countries will adapt better to it: This statement is not correct according to the passage. The passage highlights that wealthier countries are better able to adapt to and counter the deleterious effects of climate change, exacerbating the gap between rich and poor nations.

 

D. Health will be affected: This statement is supported by the passage, which mentions that advanced healthcare systems in wealthier countries can better cope with spreading tropical diseases due to climate change.

 

E. Developed countries will suffer less: This statement is not correct according to the passage. The passage highlights that climate change will exacerbate the gap between rich and poor nations, with those with the fewest resources being most vulnerable.

 

Therefore, option C and option E are the statements that are not correct in the context of climate change according to the passage.

Question 48
Climatechange will have broad impact on human society. Changes projected to occur in the coming century or two won’t have the apocalyptic, civilization-destroying character of, say an all-out nuclear war or a direct hit from a large asteroid. But climate change will be disruptive in many ways to a civilization whose planetary home is already under stress from the demands of billions of human beings.The physical impacts of climate change won’t be evenly distributed around the globe. Low-lying coastal regions, for example, will suffer more from sea-level rise, continental interiors will see more drought and high latitudes will warm disproportionately. For that reason alone, impacts will vary from country to country. But also alter the impact of changing climate, social, political and economic considerations. That’s because wealthier countries are better able to adapt to and counter deleterious effects. Wealthy countries can build protective seawalls to ward off the rising oceans; they can engineer massive water projects to ensure continuing supplies of freshwater; they can outbid poorer countries if declines in domestic agriculture require increased food imports their advanced health care systems can better cope with spreading tropical diseases; and their robust economies can speed recovery from extreme weather events. We’re forced to the unfortunate conclusion that climate change will exacerbate the gap between rich and poor nations, as those with the fewest resources will be most vulnerable. This conclusion should be especially troubling because anthropogenic climate change is almost ‘entirely the result of fossil fuel consumption, deforestation and other activities carried out by or for the benefit of the developed world.Climate change will impact the world (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Uniformly
  • B.The developing world less
  • C.Disparately
  • D.The developed world more
Correct Answer: Disparately

The passage indicates that the impacts of climate change will not be evenly distributed around the globe. Different regions will experience varying degrees and types of impacts. For example, low-lying coastal regions will suffer more from sea-level rise, continental interiors will experience more drought, and high latitudes will warm disproportionately. Additionally, social, political, and economic factors will also influence how different countries are affected by climate change. Therefore, the most appropriate term to describe the impact of climate change, based on the passage, is "disparately" (option C).

Question 49
Climate change will have broad impact on human society. Changes projected to occur in the coming century or two won’t have the apocalyptic, civilization-destroying character of, say an all-out nuclear war or a direct hit from a large asteroid. But climate change will be disruptive in many ways to a civilization whose planetary home is already under stress from the demands of billions of human beings.The physical impacts of climate change won’t be evenly distributed around the globe. Low-lying coastal regions, for example, will suffer more from sea-level rise, continental interiors will see more drought and high latitudes will warm disproportionately. For that reason alone, impacts will vary from country to country. But also alter the impact of changing climate, social, political and economic considerations. That’s because wealthier countries are better able to adapt to and counter deleterious effects. Wealthy countries can build protective seawalls to ward off the rising oceans; they can engineer massive water projects to ensure continuing supplies of freshwater; they can outbid poorer countries if declines in domestic agriculture require increased food imports their advanced health care systems can better cope with spreading tropical diseases; and their robust economies can speed recovery from extreme weather events. We’re forced to the unfortunate conclusion that climate change will exacerbate the gap between rich and poor nations, as those with the fewest resources will be most vulnerable. This conclusion should be especially troubling because anthropogenic climate change is almost ‘entirely the result of fossil fuel consumption, deforestation and other activities carried out by or for the benefit of the developed world.How will climate change affect the gap between the rich and poor countries? (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.It will be increase the gap
  • B.It will reduce the gap
  • C.There will be no change in gap
  • D.It will bridge the gap
Correct Answer: It will be increase the gap

The passage suggests that climate change will exacerbate the gap between rich and poor nations. Wealthier countries are better equipped to adapt to and mitigate the effects of climate change due to their resources and infrastructure. They can build protective measures, invest in advanced healthcare systems, and recover more quickly from extreme weather events. In contrast, poorer countries with fewer resources will be more vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. Therefore, the correct answer is option (A).

Question 50
Climate change will have broad impact on human society. Changes projected to occur in the coming century or two won’t have the apocalyptic, civilization-destroying character of, say an all-out nuclear war or a direct hit from a large asteroid. But climate change will be disruptive in many ways to a civilization whose planetary home is already under stress from the demands of billions of human beings.The physical impacts of climate change won’t be evenly distributed around the globe. Low-lying coastal regions, for example, will suffer more from sea-level rise, continental interiors will see more drought and high latitudes will warm disproportionately. For that reason alone, impacts will vary from country to country. But also alter the impact of changing climate, social, political and economic considerations. That’s because wealthier countries are better able to adapt to and counter deleterious effects. Wealthy countries can build protective seawalls to ward off the rising oceans; they can engineer massive water projects to ensure continuing supplies of freshwater; they can outbid poorer countries if declines in domestic agriculture require increased food imports their advanced health care systems can better cope with spreading tropical diseases; and their robust economies can speed recovery from extreme weather events. We’re forced to the unfortunate conclusion that climate change will exacerbate the gap between rich and poor nations, as those with the fewest resources will be most vulnerable. This conclusion should be especially troubling because anthropogenic climate change is almost ‘entirely the result of fossil fuel consumption, deforestation and other activities carried out by or for the benefit of the developed world.Given below are two statements:Statement I: The developed world can cope better with climate changeStatement II: The developed world is largely responsible for climate change.In the light of the given statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both statement I and Statement II are correct

Statement I: The developed world can cope better with climate change. This statement is supported by the passage, which discusses how wealthier countries are better able to adapt to and counter the deleterious effects of climate change due to their resources and infrastructure.

 

Statement II: The developed world is largely responsible for climate change. This statement is also supported by the passage, which mentions that anthropogenic climate change is almost entirely the result of activities carried out by or for the benefit of the developed world, such as fossil fuel consumption and deforestation.

 

Both statements align with the information provided in the passage, making option (A) Both statement I and Statement II are correct the most appropriate answer.

Quiz Attempt #119749

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
Read the passage and answer the questions given below:India needs to manage daylight much better than it does. Maximizing it is also a good place to start to be more energy efficient. Not using daylight properly comes at a cost - $4.1 billion, or 0.2% of GDP, according to a Cornell study, in addition to health impacts. Experts have suggested multiple time zones in India, perhaps reverting to the pre-1947 system of two time zones, as proposed by the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR)-National Physical Laboratory, India's official time keeper. But considering the huge investments required, as well as the logistical exercise of coordination, make this idea unattractive. Daylight savings is a more practical option.Daylight savings time, or summertime, is the system of advancing clocks by an hour to get more light out of the day. This would permit using the extra hour of daylight in summer months between March and October. And it would avoid using lights on winter mornings because the sun rises later. This system will be particularly useful in the eastern and northeastern parts of the country. To further maximize use of daylight, a shift away from uniform opening hours at workplaces can be advantageous. The sun sets roughly 90 minutes later in western parts of the country than in the eastern parts. In northeast and eastern states, establishments could begin work an hour earlier than elsewhere. It would allow people here to match their working hours to environmental cues, while giving a head start to others elsewhere.Advancing time to maximize use of daylight has energy-saving potential, which will significantly alter energy usage, cut down India's carbon footprint and help leverage the natural resource of sunlight. It's about maximizing hay when the sun shines.Daylight saving time would do all the following EXCEPTA. Advance clock by an hourB. Begin work late in all parts of the countryC. Get more light out of the dayD. Would stagger work hoursChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A & B only
  • B.B only
  • C.A, C & D only
  • D.B & D only
Correct Answer: B only

Daylight saving time involves advancing the clock by an hour to get more light out of the day and make better use of daylight. It does not necessarily mean beginning work late in all parts of the country, so option B is incorrect.

Question 2
The following table shows the number of employees of five companies A-E who prefer their own vehicle to reach office and percentage (%) of employees who prefer Metro and Bus to reach office. There are only three modes of transport as mentioned. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Company wise Distribution of Employees Preferring Modes of Transport:CompanyNumber of Employees who prefer their own VehiclesNumber of Employees who prefer MetroNumber of Employees who prefer BusA18468%24%B7860%35%C38455%30%D18270%16%E22072.5%15%Question: What is the difference between the number of employees who prefer travelling by Metro from companies D and E together and the number of employees who prefer travelling by bus from companies A, D & E together?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.1142
  • B.1162
  • C.1122
  • D.1194
Correct Answer: 1162

Number of employees in companies:

Company

Number of Employees who prefer their own Vehicles

Number of Employees who prefer Metro

Number of Employees who prefer Bus

Total Number of Employees

A

184

68%

24%

184100-(68+24) ×100 = 2300

B

78

60%

35%

78100-(60+35) ×100 = 1560

C

384

55%

30%

384100-(55+30) ×100 = 2560

D

182

70%

16%

182100-(70+16) ×100 = 1300

E

220

72.5%

15%

220100-(72.5+15) ×100 = 1760

 

Required difference = (70% of 1300 + 72.5% of 1760) – (24% of 2300 + 16% of 1300 + 15% of 1760)

= 54% of 1300 + 57.5% of 1760 - 24% of 2300

= 702 + 1012 – 552 = 1162

Question 4
The following table shows the number of employees of five companies A-E who prefer their own vehicle to reach office and percentage (%) of employees who prefer Metro and Bus to reach office. There are only three modes of transport as mentioned. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Company wise Distribution of Employees Preferring Modes of Transport:CompanyNumber of Employees who prefer their own VehiclesNumber of Employees who prefer MetroNumber of Employees who prefer BusA18468%24%B7860%35%C38455%30%D18270%16%E22072.5%15%Question:In another company P, if the number of employees who prefer travelling by Metro is 25% more than the number of employees who prefer travelling by Metro from company B and the number of employees who prefer travelling by metro from company P is 45% of the total number of employees in that company, then the total number of employees in company E is_________ % less than the total number of employees in company P.(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)

Question 5

Question 6
The following table shows the number of employees of five companies A-E who prefer their own vehicle to reach office and percentage (%) of employees who prefer Metro and Bus to reach office. There are only three modes of transport as mentioned. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Company wise Distribution of Employees Preferring Modes of Transport:CompanyNumber of Employees who prefer their own VehiclesNumber of Employees who prefer MetroNumber of Employees who prefer BusA18468%24%B7860%35%C38455%30%D18270%16%E22072.5%15%Question: What is the total number of employees who prefer travelling by Metro from A, B and C?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)

  • D.4028
