Question 7
An art teacher wants to create an interactivegallery(wall) of famous artists for her students. Which of the following tools would be the most useful?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Screencastomatic
  • B.Padlet
  • C.Edpuzzle
  • D.Mentimeter
Correct Answer: Padlet

Padlet allows users to create digital bulletin boards where they can add various types of content, such as images, text, links, videos, and documents. This would be ideal for the art teacher to curate images of famous artworks, provide information about the artists, and engage students in interactive discussions or activities related to the art pieces. It offers a visually appealing and collaborative platform for organizing and sharing art resources with students.

Question 8
If the mobile number of the friend changes and you often continue to dial his former number it an example of(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Positive transfer of learning
  • B.Negative transfer of learning
  • C.Zero transfer of learning
  • D.Bilateral transfer of learning
Correct Answer: Negative transfer of learning

Negative transfer of learning occurs when prior learning hinders or interferes with the acquisition or performance of new learning or skills. In this case, the knowledge of your friend's former mobile number is interfering with your ability to learn or remember the new number, leading to an error or mistake in dialing.

Question 9
Which of the following are the types of Implicit memory?A. Semantic memoryB. Procedural memoryC. PrimingD. Episode memoryE. Classical conditioning effectsChoose the correct option from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A & C only
  • B.C, D & E only
  • C.B, C, & E only
  • D.A & B only
Correct Answer: B, C, & E only

Implicit memory refers to the influence of experience on behaviour, even if the individual is not aware of those influences.

 

There are 3 general types of implicit memory: procedural memory, classical conditioning effects, and priming.

1. Procedural memory involves our subconscious knowledge of how to perform tasks. Examples include walking, speaking a language, operating a phone, or playing a video game. While we may not be able to articulate these processes, procedural memory enables us to execute complex actions effortlessly. This concept sheds light on how infants acquire fundamental skills like crawling and talking, which are ingrained during childhood without conscious recollection in adulthood.

2. Classical conditioning effects entail the unconscious association of neutral stimuli with other stimuli, leading to natural responses such as pleasure or salivation. Through this form of learning, a conditioned stimulus, like a sound, elicits a response similar to the unconditioned stimulus, such as food, after the association is formed.

3. Priming, the third type of implicit memory, involves changes in behavior due to frequent or recent experiences. It encompasses both the activation of knowledge (e.g., presenting words related to kindness to prime the concept) and the subsequent impact of this activation on behavior (e.g., individuals primed with kindness may exhibit more compassionate actions).

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 10
Which of the following are the ways to increase motivational climate in the class?A. Use a variety of instructional strategies to maintain student interestB. Give student opportunities to share their experiences and learning with each otherC. Allow sarcasm and superiority to exhibit in classroomD. Fostering classroom atmosphere which is based on trust and cooperationChoose the correct option from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.B & C only
  • B.C & D only
  • C.A, B, & D only
  • D.A, C & D only
Correct Answer: A, B, & D only

The correct option to increase the motivational climate in the class is option (C), i.e., A, B, & D only.

 

Using a variety of instructional strategies helps to maintain student interest by keeping the classroom dynamic and engaging.

 

Giving students opportunities to share their experiences and learning with each other fosters a sense of community and collaboration, which can enhance motivation.

 

Allowing sarcasm and superiority to exhibit in the classroom can create a negative and demotivating atmosphere, so it does not contribute to increasing the motivational climate.

 

Fostering a classroom atmosphere based on trust and cooperation is essential for creating a supportive environment where students feel valued and motivated to participate in learning.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 11
Which of the following factors influence the effectiveness of support material?A. Clarity and comprehensibilityB. Quantity of materialC. Appropriateness for the learner’s age and levelD. Relevance to the learning objectivesChoose the correct option from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A only
  • B.A, C & D only
  • C.C & D only
  • D.B & D only
Correct Answer: A, C & D only

The factors that influence the effectiveness of support material are:

1. Clarity and comprehensibility ensure that the support material is easily understood by the learners, enhancing its effectiveness.

2. The support material should be appropriate for the learner's age and level to ensure it aligns with their cognitive abilities and developmental stage.

3. Support material should be relevant to the learning objectives to facilitate learning and reinforce key concepts.

Therefore, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 12
Which among the following is NOT an advantage of open ended questions in survey research?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.They are useful for explaining areas in which researchers has limited knowledge
  • B.Respondents can answer in their own terms
  • C.They allow unusual responses to be derived
  • D.They are easy for the interviewers and or respondents to complete
Correct Answer: They are easy for the interviewers and or respondents to complete

Option D is correct.

They are useful for explaining areas in which researchers have limited knowledge is an advantage of open-ended questions. They allow respondents to provide detailed information and insights that researchers may not have considered or been aware of previously.

Respondents can answer in their own terms is another advantage. Open-ended questions allow respondents to express their thoughts and experiences in their own words, providing richer and more nuanced data compared to closed-ended questions.

They allow unusual responses to be derived is also an advantage. Open-ended questions encourage respondents to think creatively and express unconventional or unexpected perspectives, which can lead to insights that might be overlooked with closed-ended questions.

They are easy for the interviewers and/or respondents to complete is not true. Open-ended questions can be more time-consuming and challenging for both interviewers and respondents. Respondents need to articulate their thoughts in detail, while interviewers must carefully transcribe or code the responses for analysis. In contrast, closed-ended questions are typically easier to administer and analyze because they offer predefined response options.

Question 13
The reference section of a research article is written in API style. Arrange the information pertaining to a reference in the correct orderA. Page numberB. Year of publicationC. Name of authorD. Title of the articleChoose the correct option from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A, B, C, D
  • B.C, A, B, D
  • C.D, C, B, A
  • D.C, B, D, A
Correct Answer: C, B, D, A

Option D is correct.

In APA (American Psychological Association) style, the reference section of a research article typically follows the order:

Name of author: This is listed first, with the last name followed by initials (e.g., Smith, J. D.).

Year of publication: This is listed after the author's name within parentheses (e.g., (2022)).

Title of the article: This is listed next, in sentence case, followed by a period (e.g., Title of the Article.).

Page number: If the reference is to a specific article within a journal or a chapter within a book, the page number is included at the end of the reference after the title of the article or book chapter.

Question 14
Given below are two statements:Statement I: Coding is crucial stage in the process of doing a content analysisStatement II: A coding schedule includes all the dimensions that would be employed in the coding process and indication of the guidance for coderIn the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Statement I is true but Statement II is false

Option C is correct.

Statement I is true. In content analysis, coding involves systematically categorizing and labeling data based on predetermined criteria or themes. It is a fundamental step in content analysis that helps researchers organize and analyze large amounts of qualitative data.

Statement II is false. While a coding schedule or coding manual does provide guidance for coders and outlines the dimensions or categories used for coding, it does not necessarily include "all" dimensions. A coding schedule typically outlines the specific categories, criteria, and rules for coding data but may not encompass every possible dimension or aspect of the data. Additionally, it provides instructions and examples to ensure consistency and accuracy in the coding process.

Question 15
When researchers use designs that call for multiple groups, the most commonly employed test is(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Z-test
  • B.T-test for difference of means
  • C.Paired T-test
  • D.F-test
Correct Answer: F-test

Option D is correct.

When researchers use designs that call for multiple groups, such as analysis of variance (ANOVA) or regression analysis with multiple independent variables, the most commonly employed test is the F-test.

The F-test is used to compare the variances between two or more groups. In the context of ANOVA, the F-test is used to assess whether there are significant differences in the means of three or more independent groups. It compares the ratio of the variance between groups to the variance within groups.

Question 16
Identify the measures of central tendencyA.ArithmaticmeanB. MedianC. rangeD. ModeE. SeconddecileChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A, B & C only
  • B.A, B & D only
  • C.A, B, D, & E only
  • D.A, B, C, D, & E only
Correct Answer: A, B & D only

Option B is correct.

Measures of central tendency are statistics that represent the center or typical value of a dataset.

The arithmetic mean, also known as the average, is the sum of all values in a dataset divided by the number of values. It is a common measure of central tendency.

The median is the middle value of a dataset when the values are arranged in ascending or descending order. It divides the dataset into two equal parts. It is another measure of central tendency.

The mode is the most frequently occurring value in a dataset. It represents the value that appears most often and is another measure of central tendency.

Question 17
The Asian scholar who like Aristotle supported the ethical concept of ‘Golden Mean’ as applied in communication(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.AnanadaCoomaraswamy
  • B.Patanjali
  • C.Daotsu
  • D.Confucius
Correct Answer: Confucius

The Asian scholar who supported the ethical concept of 'Golden Mean' as applied in communication is Confucius.

The concept of the "Golden Mean" in Confucianism refers to the idea of moderation and balance in all aspects of life, including communication. Confucius believed that individuals should strive for harmony and balance in their interactions with others, avoiding extremes of behavior or expression. This principle encourages people to communicate with moderation, avoiding both excessive verbosity and complete silence, and to seek a middle ground in their interactions to maintain social harmony and mutual respect.

Question 18
Media literacy is considered as a(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Corporate campaign
  • B.Limited objective
  • C.Temporary fad
  • D.Continuous process
Correct Answer: Continuous process

Media literacy is the ability to access, analyze, evaluate, and create media content. It involves understanding the role of media in society, critically evaluating media messages, and being able to create media content responsibly. Since media landscapes, technologies, and messages are constantly evolving, media literacy is not a one-time achievement but an ongoing process of learning and adaptation. Therefore, it is best characterized as a continuous process rather than a corporate campaign, limited objective, or temporary fad.

Question 19
In films the elements silenced is identified as(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Auralsyntagm
  • B.Aural paradigm
  • C.Aural position
  • D.Aural resistance
Correct Answer: Aural paradigm

In films, the elements silenced are identified as "aural paradigm." This term refers to the overall sound structure or system within a film, which includes both the sounds that are present and those that are intentionally silenced or omitted. It encompasses the entire auditory experience created by the film, including dialogue, music, sound effects, and silence.

Question 20
Which of the following are the features of narrowcasting?A. large area of reachB. Weak receptionC. Limited reach in terms of geographical areaD. Noise freeE. Appropriate for specialised media channelsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A, B, C only
  • B.B, C, D only
  • C.A, C, D only
  • D.C, D, E only
Correct Answer: C, D, E only

Narrowcasting refers to the transmission of content to a specific and specialized audience, as opposed to broadcasting, which reaches a broader audience.

 

The features of narrowcasting include:

1. Limited reach in terms of geographical area: Narrowcasting targets a specific geographic area or audience segment rather than a wide geographical region.

2. Noise-free: Since narrowcasting is aimed at a smaller and more targeted audience, it can provide a more focused and noise-free communication environment.

3. Appropriate for specialized media channels: Narrowcasting is well-suited for specialized media channels that cater to specific interests, demographics, or niche markets.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option D.

Question 21
Given below are two statements:Statement I: In communication, meaning construction is a process of making choicesStatement II: Use of language for communication is a restrictive practice in public domainIn the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Statement I is true but Statement II is false

Statement I: In communication, meaning construction involves making choices, as individuals select words, symbols, and gestures to convey their intended message. Communication is an active process where senders and receivers continuously make choices regarding encoding and decoding messages.

Statement II: The use of language for communication is not inherently a restrictive practice in the public domain. Language is a fundamental tool for communication, enabling individuals to express their thoughts, ideas, and emotions. While language may impose certain constraints or limitations, such as linguistic conventions or cultural norms, it remains a versatile and adaptable means of communication. Therefore, Statement II is false.

Question 22
If an article is sold forRs. 2220, the percentage of profit earned by the shopkeeper is the same as the percentage of loss incurred on that article if it is sold forRs. 1580. At what price should the article be sold so as to make a profit of 25%.(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Rs. 2175
  • B.Rs. 2275
  • C.Rs. 2375
  • D.Rs. 2300
Correct Answer: Rs. 2375

According to the question

2220-CPCP × 100 = CP-1580CP × 100

or CP = 1900

Now, profit = 25%

SP = 1900 × 1.25 = Rs. 2375

Question 23
There are six persons in a room namely A, B, C, D, E & F.A andE are brothers. B and D are daughters of the brother of C's father. F is the sister of E and C is the only son of A's uncle. How many male and female members, respectively, are there in the room?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.3 and 3
  • B.4 and 2
  • C.2 and 4
  • D.5 and 1
Correct Answer: 3 and 3

A, E and C are males while B, D and F are females in the family.

Question 24
Find the number that can replace question mark (?) in the series given below.(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)5.5, 11, 18.5, 30, 49.5, 85, ?
  • A.134.5
  • B.152.5
  • C.101.5
  • D.141.5
Correct Answer: 152.5

Next number = 85 + 67.5 = 152.5

Question 25
A man runs 20 meters towards east and turns right, runs for 15 meters and again turns right. Now the man runs for 10 meters and again turns to his left. Now he again runs for 10 meters and turns to his left. From here the man runs for 20 meters and once more nuns to his left and runs for 12 meters. Now which direction the man is facing?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.North
  • B.South
  • C.East
  • D.West
Correct Answer: North

Clearly, the man will be facing North now.

Question 26
In a certain coding language:A. 'RED' is coded as 360B. BLACK is coded as 792How 'BLUE' will be coded in that language?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.2475
  • B.1575
  • C.1825
  • D.2520
Correct Answer: 2520

RED = 18 × 5 × 4 = 360

BLACK = 2 × 12 × 1 × 3 × 11 = 792

Similarly,

BLUE = 2 × 12 × 21 × 5 = 2520

Question 27
If the statement “Some professors are spiritualists” is given as true. Which of the following statements could be immediately inferred to be false?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.All professors are spiritualists
  • B.Some professors are spiritualists
  • C.Some spiritualists are professors
  • D.No professors are spiritualists
Correct Answer: No professors are spiritualists

It is given that type ‘I’ is true, therefore type ‘E’ will be false.

Question 28
Which of the following statements are logically equivalent to the statement “Some professors are spiritualists”?A. Some spiritualists are ProfessorsB. Some non-spiritualists are professorsC. No spiritualists are professorsD. Some Professors are not non-spiritualistsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A, B & D only
  • B.A & D only
  • C.B & C only
  • D.C & D only
Correct Answer: A & D only

Option A is conversion of given statement (type ‘I’).

Option D is obversion of given statement.

Question 29
Which of the following statements are so related that they cannot both be false, although they can both be true?A. Some professors are spiritualistsB. All professors are spiritualistsC. No professors are spiritualistsD. Some professors are non-spiritualistsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.B & C only
  • B.B & D only
  • C.A & D only
  • D.A & C only
Correct Answer: A & D only

In case of subcontrary proposition, statements are so related that they cannot both be false, although they can both be true.

Question 30
How do you give argument in four vegetarianism when you eat meat? Which fallacy is committed in this argument?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Red herring
  • B.Appeal to emotion
  • C.Ad hominem
  • D.Hasty Generalisation
Correct Answer: Ad hominem

The fallacy committed in the argument "How do you give arguments in four vegetarianism when you eat meat?" is option (C) - Ad hominem.

Ad hominem fallacy attacks the person making the argument rather than the argument itself. The argument doesn't address the content of the vegetarian arguments. Instead, it focuses on the fact that the person making the arguments eats meat, implying hypocrisy and potentially discrediting their views on vegetarianism.

Question 31
According to Classical Indian School of logical, which fallacy is committed in the following statement? “Fire is eternal because it is produced”?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Viruddha
  • B.Sadharna
  • C.Badhita
  • D.Anupasamhari
Correct Answer: Viruddha

The fallacy committed in the statement "Fire is eternal because it is produced" according to the Classical Indian School of Logic (Nyaya) is option (A) Viruddha.

Viruddha: This fallacy refers to the fallacy of the contradictory middle term. It occurs when the middle term (hetu) in a syllogism contradicts some established knowledge or principle.

The statement claims that "being produced" (hetu) leads to "eternality" (sadhya) of fire. However, according to common knowledge and experience, things that are produced (e.g., a chair, a building) are not eternal. They eventually cease to exist. This contradicts the idea that "being produced" guarantees eternality.

Question 32
Which of the following pairs of acronym and its expanded form in incorrectly matched?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.CMOS- Consistent Metal Oxide Semiconductor
  • B.DRAM- Dynamic Random Access Memory
  • C.MICR- Magnetic Ink Corrector Reader
  • D.VLSI- Very Large Scale Integration
Correct Answer: CMOS- Consistent Metal Oxide Semiconductor

Option A is correct.

The correct expansion of CMOS is Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor. CMOS technology is widely used in integrated circuits for digital logic circuits, microcontrollers, and microprocessors due to its low power consumption and high noise immunity.

Question 33
Given below are two statements: In the context of MS-WORD softwareStatement I: The tool which is used to insert decorative text in a document is called ClipartStatement II: The purpose of using keyboard shortcut CTRL+X followed by CTRL+V for a selected text paragraph in a document is to Cut and PasteIn the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Statement I is false but Statement II is true

Option D is correct.

Statement I is false. Clipart refers to pre-made images or graphics that can be inserted into a document for decorative or illustrative purposes. It typically does not refer to decorative text. The tool used to insert decorative text in a document is usually referred to as WordArt in Microsoft Word, not Clipart.

Statement II is true. In Microsoft Word (and many other software applications), the keyboard shortcut CTRL+X is used to cut selected text or objects from the document, and CTRL+V is used to paste the cut text or objects to a new location within the document or into another document. This action is commonly referred to as Cut and Paste.

Question 34
Given below are two statements:Statement I:(49)10=(31)16=(00110001)2Statement II:(7B)16=(0111011)2=(123)10In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are true

Both the statements are correct.

Question 35
Which MS-EXCEL formulae are equivalent to each other?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)A =A3+A4+A5+A6B =SUM(A3:A6)C =SUM(A3,A6)D =SUM(A3,A4,A5,A6)
  • A.A, B, & C only
  • B.A, B & D only
  • C.B & D only
  • D.C & D only
Correct Answer: A, B & D only

Option C gives sum of only cells A3 and A6. Rest options gives sum from cells A3 to A6.

Question 36
Which of the following statements A-C is/are correct aboutcyber attacks?A. Spyware prevents access to a websiteB. Virus is self-replicating malicious code on a computerC. Denial-of-service (DoS) captures all data entered using a keyboard to obtain personal dataChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A only
  • B.B only
  • C.C only
  • D.A & C only
Correct Answer: B only

Option B is correct.

Spyware is a type of malicious software that is designed to spy on a user's computer activity without their knowledge or consent. It may track keystrokes, capture personal information, or monitor browsing habits, but it does not typically prevent access to websites. Another type of cyber threat, such as a denial-of-service (DoS) attack, might be responsible for preventing access to a website.

A virus is a type of malicious software that is capable of replicating itself and spreading to other files or systems. It can cause damage to files, steal data, or disrupt computer operations. Viruses often attach themselves to executable files or documents, and they require user intervention to spread, such as opening an infected file or executing a malicious program.

A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is aimed at making a computer or network resource unavailable to its intended users by flooding it with a large volume of malicious traffic or requests. It does not capture data entered using a keyboard. However, a keylogger, which is a type of spyware, may capture keystrokes to obtain personal data.

Thus, the statement B describes a virus as self-replicating malicious code on a computer.

Question 37
Given below are two statements:Statement I: Integrated solid waste management is an approach intended help/guide/decisions about generation of wastes, recycling of materials and ultimate disposal of waste residues.Statement II: Sources reduction is not the part of Integrated Solid Waste ManagementIn the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Statement I is true but Statement II is false

Option C is correct.

Statement I is true. Integrated solid waste management (ISWM) is a comprehensive approach aimed at managing waste throughout its lifecycle, from generation to disposal. It involves various strategies such as waste reduction, recycling, composting, and proper disposal methods to minimize environmental impact and promote sustainability.

Statement II is false. Source reduction, also known as waste prevention or waste minimization, is a fundamental component of integrated solid waste management. It involves reducing the amount of waste generated at its source through measures such as product redesign, use of reusable products, and implementation of efficient manufacturing processes. Source reduction is considered the most preferable waste management strategy as it reduces the overall environmental impact of waste management practices.

Question 38
Green House Gases absorb radiation energy mostly in which of the following regions in solar spectrum?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.X-Ray
  • B.Ultraviolet
  • C.Infra-red
  • D.Visible
Correct Answer: Infra-red

Option C is correct.

Greenhouse gases absorb radiation energy mostly in the infrared region of the solar spectrum.

Solar radiation, emitted by the Sun, spans a broad spectrum of electromagnetic radiation, including X-rays, ultraviolet (UV) radiation, visible light, infrared (IR) radiation, and beyond.

When solar radiation reaches the Earth's atmosphere, some of it is reflected back to space, some is absorbed by the atmosphere, and some reaches the Earth's surface.

The Earth's surface absorbs the incoming solar radiation and then emits heat energy in the form of infrared radiation (heat).

Greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), and water vapor (H2O), are transparent to incoming solar radiation but absorb and re-radiate infrared radiation emitted by the Earth's surface. This process traps heat in the Earth's atmosphere, leading to the greenhouse effect and warming the planet.

Thus, greenhouse gases primarily absorb radiation energy in the infrared region of the solar spectrum, allowing them to capture and retain heat within the Earth's atmosphere.

Question 39
Which of the following air pollutants cause acid rain?A. Nitric oxideB. Nitrogen dioxideC. Carbon monoxideD. Sulphur dioxideE. MethaneChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A, B, C only
  • B.A, B, D only
  • C.B, C, D only
  • D.C, D, E only
Correct Answer: A, B, D only

Option B is correct.

Acid rain is caused by the emission of certain pollutants into the atmosphere, primarily sulfur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen oxides (NOx).

Nitric oxide alone is not a major contributor to acid rain. However, it can react with other pollutants in the atmosphere to form nitrogen dioxide (NO2), which is a precursor to acid rain.

Nitrogen dioxide is a major contributor to acid rain. It reacts with water vapor and oxygen in the atmosphere to form nitric acid (HNO3), contributing to the acidity of rainfall.

Carbon monoxide is not a precursor to acid rain. It is primarily emitted from incomplete combustion processes and is not directly involved in the formation of acidic precipitation.

Sulfur dioxide is another major contributor to acid rain. It reacts with water vapor and oxygen in the atmosphere to form sulfuric acid (H2SO4), which contributes to the acidity of rainfall.

Methane is not directly involved in the formation of acid rain. It is a greenhouse gas primarily associated with climate change and does not contribute to the acidity of rainfall.

Question 40
Decreasing dissolved oxygen (DO) level in a water bodyA. Severely threaten the aquatic lifeB. Is mainly caused by the oxygen demanding wastesC. Indicates the presence of biodegradable organic substancesD. Cause undesired taste and colourE. Makes it non-drinkable to human beingsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A, B, C, D only
  • B.B, C, D, E only
  • C.A, C, D, E only
  • D.A, B, D, E only
Correct Answer: A, B, C, D only

Option A is correct.

Aquatic organisms such as fish, plants, and other organisms rely on dissolved oxygen in water for survival. A decrease in dissolved oxygen levels can lead to hypoxia or anoxia, which can be fatal for aquatic organisms, severely threatening aquatic life.

Oxygen demanding wastes, such as organic matter from sewage, agricultural runoff, or industrial effluents, can consume dissolved oxygen during decomposition. This can lead to a decrease in dissolved oxygen levels in the water body, especially in areas with high levels of organic pollution.

Biodegradable organic substances can contribute to decreasing dissolved oxygen levels in water bodies as they are decomposed by bacteria and other microorganisms, consuming oxygen in the process.

Decreased dissolved oxygen levels can lead to changes in water quality, including undesirable tastes and odors, as well as changes in color. These changes can result from the growth of algae and other microorganisms in response to altered environmental conditions caused by decreased oxygen levels.

While decreasing dissolved oxygen levels can indicate poor water quality, it does not necessarily render the water non-drinkable to humans. However, other pollutants or contaminants may be present in water with low dissolved oxygen levels that could make it unsafe for human consumption.

Question 41
Given below are two statements:Statement I: Acute health effects are caused due to prolonged exposure to a chemicalStatement II: Chronic health effects occur when an individual is exposed for a very short periodIn the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are false

Option B is correct.

Statement I is false. Acute health effects refer to adverse health effects that occur shortly after exposure to a chemical or pollutant. These effects typically occur after short-term or immediate exposure and may include symptoms such as nausea, dizziness, skin irritation, or respiratory issues. Prolonged exposure to certain chemicals may lead to chronic health effects rather than acute ones.

Statement II is also false. Chronic health effects refer to adverse health effects that develop over a long period, typically as a result of repeated or prolonged exposure to a chemical or pollutant. These effects may include diseases such as cancer, cardiovascular diseases, or respiratory diseases. Short-term exposure is more likely to cause acute health effects rather than chronic ones.

Question 42
Which education commission suggested the development of some universities into senior universities?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Sargent commission
  • B.Radhakrishnancommission
  • C.Mudaliarcommission
  • D.Kothari commission
Correct Answer: Kothari commission

Option D is correct.

The Kothari Commission, officially known as the Education Commission (1964-1966), was one of the most significant commissions in the history of education in India. It was chaired by Dr. Daulat Singh Kothari. One of the recommendations made by the Kothari Commission was the development of certain universities into senior universities. This recommendation aimed to enhance the quality of higher education by focusing on specific universities and providing them with resources and support to become centres of excellence in education and research.

Question 43
What were the recommendation of Hunter commission on higher education in India?A. The Government should leave the management of higher education to Indians themselvesB. Government colleges should be established only where the demand existedC. The Government should provide grants to non-government collegesD. Students should study the prescribed subjects without any optionE. There were no need for moral education in collegesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A, B, C only
  • B.B, C, D only
  • C.C, D, E only
  • D.A, D, E only
Correct Answer: A, B, C only

Option A is correct.

The Hunter Commission, officially known as the Indian Universities Commission, was established in 1882 and was chaired by William Wilson Hunter. Its objective was to evaluate the state of higher education in India and make recommendations for its improvement.

The Government should leave the management of higher education to Indians themselves: This recommendation reflects the sentiment of promoting indigenous control and management of higher education institutions in India. It advocated for greater involvement of Indians in the governance and administration of educational institutions, rather than having it solely controlled by the British colonial government.

Government colleges should be established only where the demand existed: This recommendation suggests a pragmatic approach to the establishment of government colleges, emphasizing the importance of assessing local demand and need before establishing new educational institutions. It aimed to ensure that resources were allocated efficiently and that colleges were established where they were most needed.

The Government should provide grants to non-government colleges: This recommendation proposed financial support from the government to non-government colleges to assist in their development and improvement. It recognized the valuable contribution of non-government institutions to the education sector and aimed to provide them with the necessary resources to maintain and enhance educational standards.

Question 44
The Committee for evolution of the New Education Policy (2016) proposed the establishment of a council for(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Private universities
  • B.Foreign universities
  • C.Educational universities
  • D.Excellence universities
Correct Answer: Excellence universities

Option D is correct.

The Committee for Evolution of the New Education Policy (2016), also known as the T.S.R. Subramanian Committee, was constituted by the Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India, to draft a New Education Policy for the country. This committee submitted its report in 2016, outlining various recommendations for the improvement of the education system in India.

One of the key recommendations proposed by the committee was the establishment of a council for Excellence universities. This council was envisioned to oversee and support universities that strive for excellence in various aspects of higher education, including teaching, research, innovation, and institutional governance. The aim was to provide these universities with the necessary resources, autonomy, and guidance to become world-class institutions of higher learning.

Question 45
Which among the following thinkers observed that the light and heat are only different forms of the same essential substance and also speaks of gravity as the cause of falling?(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Nagarjuna
  • B.Jivaka
  • C.Kanad
  • D.Ramanuj
Correct Answer: Kanad

Option C is correct.

Kanad, also known as Kashyapa, was an ancient Indian philosopher and sage who is credited with founding the Vaisheshika school of philosophy. He is best known for his work in metaphysics and atomism.

Kanad proposed the concept that light and heat are only different forms of the same essential substance. This idea reflects his understanding of the interconnectedness of various natural phenomena and the underlying unity of the universe.

Kanad also spoke about gravity as the cause of falling. While his understanding of gravity may not align exactly with modern scientific theories, his observations and insights into the nature of physical phenomena were significant contributions to ancient Indian philosophy and science.

Question 46
Given below are two statements:Statement I: Indira Gandhi National Open University (IGNOU) was set up by an Act of Parliament (1965)Statement II: IGNOU adopted the strategy of using integrated multimedia instructions throughGyanDarshanandGyanVaniIn the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Statement I is false but Statement II is true

Option D is correct.

Statement I is false. Indira Gandhi National Open University (IGNOU) was actually established through an Act of Parliament in 1985, not 1965. It was founded with the aim of providing higher education opportunities to a wide range of students through distance and open learning methods.

Statement II is true. IGNOU has adopted the strategy of using integrated multimedia instructions through platforms such as Gyan Darshan (educational television channel) and Gyan Vani (educational radio channel). These platforms are utilized to disseminate educational content to learners across the country, particularly those enrolled in IGNOU's distance education programs. The use of multimedia instruction allows IGNOU to reach a diverse student population and enhance the learning experience through various mediums.

Question 47
Read the passage and answer the questions given below:India needs to manage daylight much better than it does. Maximizing it is also a good place to start to be more energy efficient. Not using daylight properly comes at a cost - $4.1 billion, or 0.2% of GDP, according to a Cornell study, in addition to health impacts. Experts have suggested multiple time zones in India, perhaps reverting to the pre-1947 system of two time zones, as proposed by the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR)-National Physical Laboratory, India's official time keeper. But considering the huge investments required, as well as the logistical exercise of coordination, make this idea unattractive. Daylight savings is a more practical option.Daylight savings time, or summertime, is the system of advancing clocks by an hour to get more light out of the day. This would permit using the extra hour of daylight in summer months between March and October. And it would avoid using lights on winter mornings because the sun rises later. This system will be particularly useful in the eastern and northeastern parts of the country. To further maximize use of daylight, a shift away from uniform opening hours at workplaces can be advantageous. The sun sets roughly 90 minutes later in western parts of the country than in the eastern parts. In northeast and eastern states, establishments could begin work an hour earlier than elsewhere. It would allow people here to match their working hours to environmental cues, while giving a head start to others elsewhere.Advancing time to maximize use of daylight has energy-saving potential, which will significantly alter energy usage, cut down India's carbon footprint and help leverage the natural resource of sunlight. It's about maximizing hay when the sun shines.Pre 1947 India used the system ofA. Multiple time zonesB. Two time zonesC. One time zoneD. Daylight saving timeChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A & B only
  • B.B only
  • C.C & D only
  • D.B, C & D only
Correct Answer: B only

Pre-1947 India used the system of two time zones, as proposed by the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR)-National Physical Laboratory, India's official timekeeper. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer.

Question 48
Read the passage and answer the questions given below:India needs to manage daylight much better than it does. Maximizing it is also a good place to start to be more energy efficient. Not using daylight properly comes at a cost - $4.1 billion, or 0.2% of GDP, according to a Cornell study, in addition to health impacts. Experts have suggested multiple time zones in India, perhaps reverting to the pre-1947 system of two time zones, as proposed by the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR)-National Physical Laboratory, India's official time keeper. But considering the huge investments required, as well as the logistical exercise of coordination, make this idea unattractive. Daylight savings is a more practical option.Daylight savings time, or summertime, is the system of advancing clocks by an hour to get more light out of the day. This would permit using the extra hour of daylight in summer months between March and October. And it would avoid using lights on winter mornings because the sun rises later. This system will be particularly useful in the eastern and northeastern parts of the country. To further maximize use of daylight, a shift away from uniform opening hours at workplaces can be advantageous. The sun sets roughly 90 minutes later in western parts of the country than in the eastern parts. In northeast and eastern states, establishments could begin work an hour earlier than elsewhere. It would allow people here to match their working hours to environmental cues, while giving a head start to others elsewhere.Advancing time to maximize use of daylight has energy-saving potential, which will significantly alter energy usage, cut down India's carbon footprint and help leverage the natural resource of sunlight. It's about maximizing hay when the sun shines.Having multiple time zones or two time zones is not a practical option becauseA. It cannot be doneB. The costs involved are hugeC. It will serve no purposeD. The logistical exercise of co-ordination will be neededChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A, B & C only
  • B.A, B & D only
  • C.C & D only
  • D.B & D only
Correct Answer: B & D only

According to the passage, having multiple time zones or two time zones is not a practical option mainly because of the huge costs involved and the logistical exercise of coordination that would be needed. Therefore, options B and D are correct.

Question 49
Read the passage and answer the questions given below:India needs to manage daylight much better than it does. Maximizing it is also a good place to start to be more energy efficient. Not using daylight properly comes at a cost - $4.1 billion, or 0.2% of GDP, according to a Cornell study, in addition to health impacts. Experts have suggested multiple time zones in India, perhaps reverting to the pre-1947 system of two time zones, as proposed by the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR)-National Physical Laboratory, India's official time keeper. But considering the huge investments required, as well as the logistical exercise of coordination, make this idea unattractive. Daylight savings is a more practical option.Daylight savings time, or summertime, is the system of advancing clocks by an hour to get more light out of the day. This would permit using the extra hour of daylight in summer months between March and October. And it would avoid using lights on winter mornings because the sun rises later. This system will be particularly useful in the eastern and northeastern parts of the country. To further maximize use of daylight, a shift away from uniform opening hours at workplaces can be advantageous. The sun sets roughly 90 minutes later in western parts of the country than in the eastern parts. In northeast and eastern states, establishments could begin work an hour earlier than elsewhere. It would allow people here to match their working hours to environmental cues, while giving a head start to others elsewhere.Advancing time to maximize use of daylight has energy-saving potential, which will significantly alter energy usage, cut down India's carbon footprint and help leverage the natural resource of sunlight.It's about maximizing hay when the sun shines.India needs to manage daylight much better than it does in order toA. Be more energy efficientB. Reduce in carbon foot printC. Maximize the use of natural resource of sunlightChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.A, B & C
  • B.A only
  • C.A & C only
  • D.B only
Correct Answer: A, B & C

The passage suggests advancing time to maximize use of daylight has energy-saving potential (option A), which will significantly alter energy usage, cut down India's carbon footprint (option B) and help leverage the natural resource of sunlight (Option C).

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (A).

Question 50
Read the passage and answer the questions given below:India needs to manage daylight much better than it does. Maximizing it is also a good place to start to be more energy efficient. Not using daylight properly comes at a cost - $4.1 billion, or 0.2% of GDP, according to a Cornell study, in addition to health impacts. Experts have suggested multiple time zones in India, perhaps reverting to the pre-1947 system of two time zones, as proposed by the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR)-National Physical Laboratory, India's official time keeper. But considering the huge investments required, as well as the logistical exercise of coordination, make this idea unattractive. Daylight savings is a more practical option.Daylight savings time, or summertime, is the system of advancing clocks by an hour to get more light out of the day. This would permit using the extra hour of daylight in summer months between March and October. And it would avoid using lights on winter mornings because the sun rises later. This system will be particularly useful in the eastern and northeastern parts of the country. To further maximize use of daylight, a shift away from uniform opening hours at workplaces can be advantageous. The sun sets roughly 90 minutes later in western parts of the country than in the eastern parts. In northeast and eastern states, establishments could begin work an hour earlier than elsewhere. It would allow people here to match their working hours to environmental cues, while giving a head start to others elsewhere.Advancing time to maximize use of daylight has energy-saving potential, which will significantly alter energy usage, cut down India's carbon footprint and help leverage the natural resource of sunlight. It's about maximizing hay when the sun shines.Given below are two statements:Statement I: Daylight savings time would permit using the extra hour of Daylight from March to October.Statement II: Uniform opening hours at all workplaces will maximize use of daylight.In the light of the given statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.Both statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Statement I is true but Statement II is false

Statement I in the passage is true: Daylight savings time indeed permits using the extra hour of daylight from March to October. However, Statement II is false. The passage suggests a shift away from uniform opening hours at workplaces, not uniformity, to maximize the use of daylight. Therefore, the correct answer is option (C), i.e., Statement I is true but Statement II is false.

Quiz Attempt #119750

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
Table – 1 below shows the percentage distribution of candidates who qualified in a competitive examination from six different states A and F during the two years 2021 and 2022, along with the ratio of Males to females among them and Table – 2 shows the total number of candidates who appeared and percentage of candidates who qualified from all the six states A-F in same two years. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Table – 1 State-wise Details of Qualified Candidates in 2021 and 2022:Year/State20212022Qualified (%)Male:FemaleQualified (%)Male:FemaleA18%5:420%28:17B16%3:112%5:3C12%7:516%11:5D16%13:1115%15:11E25%13:1222%15:9F13%8:115%11:9Table – 2 Year-wise Details of Appeared and Qualified (%) Candidates:YearTotal Appeared from state A-FPercentage (%) Qualified from state A-F202114200045%202218000052%Question: The number of female candidates who qualified from state B in 2021 is approximately --------- % of the male candidates who qualified from stateAin 2022.(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
  • A.16
  • B.22
  • C.20
  • D.18
Correct Answer: 22

Question 4
Table – 1 below shows the percentage distribution of candidates who qualified in a competitive examination from six different states A and F during the two years 2021 and 2022, along with the ratio of Males to females among them and Table – 2 shows the total number of candidates who appeared and percentage of candidates who qualified from all the six states A-F in same two years. Question 5
Table – 1 below shows the percentage distribution of candidates who qualified in a competitive examination from six different states A and F during the two years 2021 and 2022, along with the ratio of Males to females among them and Table – 2 shows the total number of candidates who appeared and percentage of candidates who qualified from all the six states A-F in same two years. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Table – 1 State-wise Details of Qualified Candidates in 2021 and 2022:Year/State20212022Qualified (%)Male:FemaleQualified (%)Male:FemaleA18%5:420%28:17B16%3:112%5:3C12%7:516%11:5D16%13:1115%15:11E25%13:1222%15:9F13%8:115%11:9Table – 2 Year-wise Details of Appeared and Qualified (%) Candidates:YearTotal Appeared from state A-FPercentage (%) Qualified from state A-F202114200045%202218000052%Question: In the year 2021, the number of female candidates who qualified is more than 5000 in exactly ---------------- sites.(UGC NET Paper 1 June 2023)
